paper_title: Facile synthesis of MoS2/Bi2WO6 nanocomposites for enhanced CO2 photoreduction activity under visible light irradiation

catalyst.source: The few layered MoS 2 as a cocatalyst has intimate interactions with the hierarchical flower-like Bi 2 WO 6 microspheres, which boosts the visible light harvesting and charge transferring, and promotes the separation of electron-hole pairs, thus leading to the superior photocatalytic activity.
catalyst.context: A novel composite material, MoS 2 /Bi 2 WO 6 , has been fabricated via a facile two-step approach.The few layered MoS 2 as a cocatalyst has intimate interactions with the hierarchical flower-like Bi 2 WO 6 microspheres, which boosts the visible light harvesting and charge transferring, and promotes the separation of electron-hole pairs, thus leading to the superior photocatalytic activity.It was found that the as-synthesized MoS 2 /Bi 2 WO 6 nanocomposites exhibited significantly enhanced performance for the photoreduction of CO 2 into hydrocarbons, i.e. methanol and ethanol, as compared with pure Bi 2 WO 6 .The yields of methanol and ethanol obtained over the composite with optimal content of MoS 2 (0.4 wt) were 36.7 and 36.6 mol gcat -1 after 4 h of visible light irradiation, respectively, which were 1.94 times higher than that over pure Bi 2 WO 6 .Furthermore, the mechanism of CO 2 photoreduction was also investigated.It indicates that the CO 3 2-, HCO 3 -and H 2 CO 3 generated in CO 2 aqueous solution would be the reactive substrates during the photoreduction reaction, proving the thermodynamic feasibility of CO 2 photoreduction.This work demonstrated that MoS 2 is a very promising candidate for development of highly active photocatalysts, and supplied a facile and simple strategy for designing environmentally benign, cheap non-noble metal, and highly efficient semiconductor composites.

catalyst.source: The obtained (NH 4 ) 2 MoS 4 /Bi 2 WO 6 precursor was calcined at 673 K for 2 h in an Ar atmosphere to form the MoS 2 /Bi 2 WO 6 nanocomposites.
catalyst.context: All reagents were analytical grade and used as purchased, without further purification.(NH 4 ) 2 MoS 4 was prepared according to the literature 29. Hierarchical flower-like Bi 2 WO 6 microspheres were synthesized by a simple hydrothermal process.In a typical procedure, 2 mmol Bi(NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O was dissolved in 5 mL glacial acetic acid, and the solution was stirred for 20 min.A white colloidal suspension formed when 30 mL 0.042 mol L -1 Na 2 WO 4 aqueous solution was dropwise added into the above solution.After being stirred for another 2 h, the suspension was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, and maintained at 180 Bi 2 WO 6 (1.0 g) was added into 5 mL ethanol solution containing designated amount of (NH 4 ) 2 MoS 4 .The above suspension was stirred at room temperature for several hours to remove the ethanol.The obtained (NH 4 ) 2 MoS 4 /Bi 2 WO 6 precursor was calcined at 673 K for 2 h in an Ar atmosphere to form the MoS 2 /Bi 2 WO 6 nanocomposites.The samples with different theoretical loading amount of MoS 2 , i.e. 0.2, 0.3, 0.4 and 0.5, were denoted as 2MB, 3MB, 4MB and 5MB, respectively.Moreover, pure MoS 2 was prepared through the calcination of pure (NH 4 ) 2 MoS 4 at 673 K for 2 h under the Ar atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Bruker AXS-D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with Cu K radiation in the 2A range of 10-70 .The morphologies and microstructures of the samples were observed by means of the field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Nova NanoSEM 450) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL JEM-2100).The UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were recorded at room temperature on a Hitachi U-3900H instrument with an integrating sphere attachment using BaSO 4 as the reference in the wavelength range of 300-800 nm.X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted using a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD (delay line detector) spectrometer with an Al K radiation line source.All the binding energies for the high-resolution spectra were calibrated by setting C 1s to 284.6 eV.The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were measured using a Hitachi F4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer with an excitation wavelength of 300 nm at room temperature. Electrochemical measurements were carried out on a CHI 660D electrochemical workstation (Chenhua Instrument Co., Shanghai) with a standard three-electrode system.Fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) deposited with the as-prepared samples served as a working electrode with an active area of catalyst 1.0 cm 2 , while the counter and the reference electrodes were graphite and saturated calomel electrode respectively.The Mott-Schottky measurement was performed at fixed frequency of 1000 Hz with 5 mV amplitude and photocurrents measurements was performed at a 300 W Xe lamp equipped with an ultraviolet cut off filter ( 420 nm) served as the visible light source.A 0.5 M Na 2 SO 4 aqueous solution was used as the electrolyte.The electrochemical impedance spectroscopies (EIS) were recorded in the frequency range of 100 kHz-0.01Hz, and the applied bias voltage and ac amplitude were set at open-circuit voltage. The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was operated in a 200 mL quartz glass reactor at 4 C and atmospheric pressure, similar to our previously reported procedures 30,31.Typically, 50 mg catalyst was suspended into 50 mL deionized water under magnetic stirring, and high purity CO 2 gas (99.995) was continuously bubbled through the solution at the rate of 50 mL min -1 .A 300 W Xe arc lamp (PLS-SXE300) equipped with an ultraviolet cutoff filter ( 420 nm) was positioned 5 cm above from the reactor as a light resource.Prior to irradiation, CO 2 gas was bubbled into above solution for 30 min to expel dissolved oxygen in the reaction system.After turning on the lamp, 2 mL of suspension was sampled at certain time intervals and centrifuged to remove the photocatalyst particles.The products were qualitatively analyzed by an Agilent Technologies 7890A gas chromatograph (FID detector, DB-WAX column) through observing and comparing the chromatographic peaks with those for the authentic methanol standard and ethanol standard.

catalyst.source: The Bi 2 WO 6 -based nanocomposites containing few layered MoS 2 as cocatalyst were successfully synthesized by a facile method, and afforded as effective photocatalysts for the photoreduction of CO 2 into hydrocarbons under visible light irradiation ( 420 nm).
catalyst.context: The Bi 2 WO 6 -based nanocomposites containing few layered MoS 2 as cocatalyst were successfully synthesized by a facile method, and afforded as effective photocatalysts for the photoreduction of CO 2 into hydrocarbons under visible light irradiation ( 420 nm).The as-prepared MoS 2 /Bi 2 WO 6 nanocomposites showed an excellent CO 2 photoreduction performance, dramatically higher than pure Bi 2 WO 6 .Over the optimal sample consisting of 0.4 wt MoS 2 (4MB), the yields of methanol and ethanol can be achieved 36.7 and 36.6 mol gcat -1 respectively, after 4 h of visible light irradiation.The total hydrocarbons yield over 4MB is about 1.94 folds to that over pure Bi 2 WO 6 .A possible photocatalytic mechanism is also proposed.It is believed that the CO 3 2-, HCO 3 -and H 2 CO 3 formed in CO 2 aqueous solution could act as the reactive carbon sources during the photoreduction reaction, which proves that the photoreduction of CO 2 in water is a thermodynamically feasible process.Furthermore, the remarkable improved photocatalytic activity by introducing MoS 2 could be ascribed to the intimate interactions between MoS 2 and Bi 2 WO 6 , and the superior conductivity of MoS 2 , which efficiently improve the interfacial charge transfer and promote the separation of electron-hole pairs in the composite.This study opens a promising prospect for the development of cost-effective, environmental friendly, and efficient semiconductor-based composite photocatalysts. Electrochemical measurements were carried out on a CHI 660D electrochemical workstation (Chenhua Instrument Co., Shanghai) with a standard three-electrode system.Fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) deposited with the as-prepared samples served as a working electrode with an active area of catalyst 1.0 cm 2 , while the counter and the reference electrodes were graphite and saturated calomel electrode respectively.The Mott-Schottky measurement was performed at fixed frequency of 1000 Hz with 5 mV amplitude and photocurrents measurements was performed at a 300 W Xe lamp equipped with an ultraviolet cut off filter ( 420 nm) served as the visible light source.A 0.5 M Na 2 SO 4 aqueous solution was used as the electrolyte.The electrochemical impedance spectroscopies (EIS) were recorded in the frequency range of 100 kHz-0.01Hz, and the applied bias voltage and ac amplitude were set at open-circuit voltage. The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was operated in a 200 mL quartz glass reactor at 4 C and atmospheric pressure, similar to our previously reported procedures 30,31.Typically, 50 mg catalyst was suspended into 50 mL deionized water under magnetic stirring, and high purity CO 2 gas (99.995) was continuously bubbled through the solution at the rate of 50 mL min -1 .A 300 W Xe arc lamp (PLS-SXE300) equipped with an ultraviolet cutoff filter ( 420 nm) was positioned 5 cm above from the reactor as a light resource.Prior to irradiation, CO 2 gas was bubbled into above solution for 30 min to expel dissolved oxygen in the reaction system.After turning on the lamp, 2 mL of suspension was sampled at certain time intervals and centrifuged to remove the photocatalyst particles.The products were qualitatively analyzed by an Agilent Technologies 7890A gas chromatograph (FID detector, DB-WAX column) through observing and comparing the chromatographic peaks with those for the authentic methanol standard and ethanol standard.

reaction medium.context: A novel composite material, MoS 2 /Bi 2 WO 6 , has been fabricated via a facile two-step approach.The few layered MoS 2 as a cocatalyst has intimate interactions with the hierarchical flower-like Bi 2 WO 6 microspheres, which boosts the visible light harvesting and charge transferring, and promotes the separation of electron-hole pairs, thus leading to the superior photocatalytic activity.It was found that the as-synthesized MoS 2 /Bi 2 WO 6 nanocomposites exhibited significantly enhanced performance for the photoreduction of CO 2 into hydrocarbons, i.e. methanol and ethanol, as compared with pure Bi 2 WO 6 .The yields of methanol and ethanol obtained over the composite with optimal content of MoS 2 (0.4 wt) were 36.7 and 36.6 mol gcat -1 after 4 h of visible light irradiation, respectively, which were 1.94 times higher than that over pure Bi 2 WO 6 .Furthermore, the mechanism of CO 2 photoreduction was also investigated.It indicates that the CO 3 2-, HCO 3 -and H 2 CO 3 generated in CO 2 aqueous solution would be the reactive substrates during the photoreduction reaction, proving the thermodynamic feasibility of CO 2 photoreduction.This work demonstrated that MoS 2 is a very promising candidate for development of highly active photocatalysts, and supplied a facile and simple strategy for designing environmentally benign, cheap non-noble metal, and highly efficient semiconductor composites.
